--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> >I was trying to kill two birds with one stone, by keeping 
innovations
> >matched throughout a population A) I think this is a better 
approach
> >then just keeping track of new innovations and B) It solves the 
problem
> >with crossover. But since it's not going to work with distributed 
NEAT
> >and also if say you load a seed population that already has 
matching
> >connections. I think I will have to do as you say - and maybe try 
and
> >maintain innovation numbers across the population as well if I 
can.
> 
> Here's a thought...  Why give connections a unique innovation 
number at all? 
>   Why not assign their unique ID based on the innovation numbers 
of the 
> nodes they connect?  If you create a new connection between nodes 
253 and 
> 275, then the ID for the connection could be "253:275".  Store the 
> connections in a hash table, and you have instant prevention of 
duplicates.  
> Then, even if a connection is created 10 generations later, if it 
connects 
> the same nodes, it's the same gene.  Even if the organism has 
subsequently 
> gone off and formed its own species.
> 
> Any reason why that wouldn't work?

I think sometimes it may be desirable to assign a different 
innovation number connecting two of the same nodes.  This goes back 
to the debate about how long to keep a record of innovation 
numbers.  In the FAQ I give some reasons I chose to only keep them 
around for 1 generation.  In your proposed model, this wouldn't be 
an option.  Also, it's nice to know the order that connections 
appeared.  If you ever look at a NEAT genome you can tell how often 
connections are successful and in what order they were put togther 
by looking at their innovation numbers.  Aside from these concerns, 
your idea is still doable but you'd lose these capabilities.

ken
